Citation: Ortet Lopes, Ivandro, Deqing Zou, Francis A. Ruambo, Saeed Akbar, and Bin Yuan. "Towards effective detection of recent DDoS attacks: A deep learning approach." Security and Communication Networks 2021, no. 1 (2021): 5710028.
Objective: To propose CyDDoS, a lightweight, deep-learning-based IDS framework for detecting recent DDoS attacks, reducing system processing overhead by integrating ensemble feature selection techniques with a deep neural network (DNN).
Algorithm used: Deep Neural Network (DNN)
Imp feaures: Features derived via ensemble ranking algorithms, including metrics like packet length, flow duration, and others selected based on thresholds or feature weights
Preprocessing technique: Removal of irrelevant features, handling missing values using the median, categorical variable embedding, and Z-score normalization
Hyperparameters: Adaptive learning rate (cyclical strategy), batch size = 1024, epochs = 5, and parameters tuned for optimal performance
Metrics used: Accuracy, Precision, Recall, F1 Score, AUC
Accuracy: Achieved accuracy of 99.6% with ROC value near 0.998
General observation: The CyDDoS system demonstrated superior detection of DDoS attacks while reducing computational overhead by 89% in terms of features from the dataset. Ensemble methods significantly improved classification metrics, and the use of GPU enhanced prediction performance.
Next steps: Plans to extend CyDDoS for multiclass DDoS attack detection, integration with controllers for real-time traffic filtering, and applying Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) techniques to improve model interpretability.
Facts: The framework showed efficient, real-time detection capabilities with reduced processing time, leveraging an ensemble of machine learning algorithms for feature selection. It significantly outperformed classical ML methods and state-of-the-art DL models.
